Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2020: Elucidating the relationship between host divergence and gut microbiome divergence in Parulid warblers
Award.AbstractNarration: This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2020, Broadening Participation of Groups Under-represented in Biology. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow that will increase the participation of groups underrepresented in biology. Living organisms are hosts to a diversity of microscopic creatures. While some of these microbes can be harmful to their host, others can be beneficial, for example by breaking down complex sugars that their host can digest. In animals, microbes are highly concentrated in the digestive tract (or gut) where they perform specialized functions. Previous research has shown that different animal species harbor unique sets of gut microbes but the role gut microbes play in the evolution of new species is not well known. This research will investigate the relationship between bird species formation and the composition of microbial communities in their guts. The fellow will design and implement educational activities integrating concepts from bird biology, microbiology and genetics that will foster the inclusion of middle school, high school, and college students underrepresented in Biology.<br/><br/>This project will use wood warblers as a study system to investigate the role of symbiotic gut microbes in the origin and maintenance of biodiversity. To address this, the fellow will sequence gut microbiomes of warblers at several sites in North America, including across two naturally-occurring hybrid zones. Interspecific hybridization may result in disruption of the gut microbiome contributing to reproductive isolation, which is necessary for the maintenance of species boundaries. By taking advantage of overlapping range distributions and natural admixture, this project will distinguish between the influence of the environment and host genetics in structuring the gut microbiome and test the hypothesis that gut microbiome divergence contributes to host reproductive isolation. This study will advance understanding of gut microbiome diversity in wild bird populations, where data are especially lacking. The fellow will develop and lead an educational activity on bird biology for middle school students from underprivileged communities in the Higher Achievement program. The fellow will also establish a DNA Day chapter at the host institution and organize an annual outreach program to be implemented in regional high schools with high rates of Hispanic student enrollment. Finally, the fellow will mentor an undergraduate and local high school student from an underrepresented background on an independent research project related to the study via the EnvironMentors program at the host institution.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated the relationship between the evolutionary divergence of warbler species and the community of bacteria living in their gut (“the gut microbiome"). This research is among the first to explore microbiome diversity across a songbird family, including within hybrid zones—geographic areas where divergent species interbreed and produce hybrid offspring. During the award period, I analyzed samples collected from over 600 birds representing 17 different species. Using bacterial DNA sequencing, I discovered that closely related warbler species have more similar gut microbiomes than distantly related species. I hypothesized this effect may be explained by host genetic factors since we found little influence of geographic locality, diet diversity, or sampling time. By analyzing samples from the Blue-winged warbler x Golden-winged warbler hybrid zone, I found that there are specific gut bacteria that associate primarily with one species or the other. Similarly, hybrids also carry a unique bacterial strain. This suggests host genetics may in fact shape their gut microbiome. I also found that abundances of certain bacteria are correlated with host color phenotype, and these bacteria are capable of processing carotenoid pigments. Because warblers derive their yellow plumage from carotenoid pigments, this may suggest birds take advantage of pigments derived by bacteria living in their gut. However, the functional significance of these bacteria remains a target for future study. I will further investigate the role of host genetics by analyzing samples from the Myrtle warbler x Audubon’s warbler hybrid zone. With this study system, I also produced genomic DNA sequences from the birds which I will analyze along with the bacterial DNA to identify candidate regions in the warbler genome that underlie gut microbiome assembly.

This research fostered the inclusion of groups underrepresented in Biology in two major ways. First, I established an annual science outreach event called “DNA Day at PSU”. I worked with Latinx PSU student groups and the Office of Science Outreach to identify local high schools and communities with high rates of enrollment by Hispanic students, and students from other marginalized communities. For the events, I recruited scientists from PSU to serve as role models and visit these local schools to talk about their paths in research and teach lesson plans on the ecology and evolution of the microbiome and other current topics in genomics. The program is now recognized as an official student group on campus with a faculty advisor in the department of Biology, and it will continue to operate annually by a graduate student board. Second, I mentored a Latinx undergraduate student on a microbiome project related to my research. She presented her work to her peers in the REU program, and at an undergraduate research showcase at PSU. She was accepted into a graduate program and is currently working on her thesis.
